#Text=A First Nations totem pole which was removed from Canada under controversial circumstances and eventually repatriated from Sweden .
#Text=It is the first Canadian totem pole repatriated from Europe .
#Text=The Haisla are a Canadian Indigenous group based out of the Kitimaat area of the North Coast of British Columbia with an approximate membership of 1500 people ( Haisla First Nation nd ) .

#Text=The modern Haisla First Nation is an amalgamation of two groups which came together in 1947 : the Douglas and Devastation Channel Kitamaat ( who call themselves Haisla ) and the Kitlope ( who call themselves Henaksiala ) of the upper Princess Royal Channel and Gardner Canal .
#Text=According to their website , “ the Haisla social system is based on matrilineal clans .

#Text=Eight clans ( Eagle , Beaver , Crow , Killer Whale , Wolf , Frog , Raven , and Salmon ) make up the community , with each clan having its own chief , its own resources areas , and its own winter village ” ( Haisla First Nation nd ) .
#Text=The 1918 influenza pandemic killed the entire Wolf and Frog clans and decimated the population , leaving less than 300 Haisla alive .

#Text=This massive population drop , which followed numerous other epidemics due to European contact , had a profound effect on the Haisla , disrupting their traditional protection of cultural objects .

#Text=The Totem Pole In 1872 , the leader of the Eagle Clan , Chief G ’ psgolox , commissioned the carving of a totem pole to honor an experience he had with the spirit Tsooda following the death of his children from smallpox .

#Text=Carved by two members of the Raven clan , Humdzeed ( Johnny Paul ) and Wakas ( Solomon Robertson ) , the pole was erected in Misk ’ usa , a Henaksiala village , where it stood for over 50 years .
#Text=In Henaksiala culture , totem poles were tied to a complex system of wealth display : part of the prestige and status system associated with the potlach .
#Text=A potlach was the traditional way to celebrate the erection of a pole .

#Text=A flowering of totem pole carving occurred due to the initial shift in local wealth following early 19th century European contact , but carving slowed mid-century due to massive population loss from disease .

#Text=Carving was further curtailed in 1884 when the Canadian government outlawed the potlach and , in 1894 , began the mandatory removal of Indigenous children to “ residential schools ” preventing traditional arts from being taught to younger generations .
#Text=Removing the Pole In December of 1927 the Swedish vice consul to British Columbia , Olof Hansson , began the process of bagging the G ’ psgolox totem pole for Sweden ’ s Museum of Ethnography .
#Text=Hansson was notified about the location of the pole by an indigenous agent .

#Text=The vice consul contacted the Canadian Department of Indian Affairs to ask for the pole and they granted his request a month later , stating that because the location where the pole stood was “ uninhabited ” , the piece was Sweden ’ s provided that Hansson could convince the Henaksiala to part with it .
#Text=Both researchers and the modern Haisla have challenged the assertion that the site was abandoned .
#Text=The Henaksiala moved through a series of locations throughout the year due to seasonal food availability and were likely not in Misk ’ usa for that reason .
#Text=This is confirmed by reports that the Henaksiala discovered the pole was missing when they returned to Misk ’ usa to fish .
#Text=The stipulation from the Canadian government that Hansson obtain permission from the pole ’ s owners before removal is a matter of controversy .
#Text=Hansson claimed in the contemporary Swedish press that although he was able to convince younger Henaksiala to sell him the totem pole , older Henaksiala had resisted .

#Text=Representatives of the Museum of Ethnography have claimed that the sale of the pole was properly negotiated , however they have no receipt for the purchase nor do they have any record of the terms of the sale , only a Canadian export license .
#Text=Louisa Smith , the great-great grand daughter of Chief G ’ psgolox , maintains that the pole was taken without the permission of her family .
#Text=All of this put the removal of the pole in a precarious legal position .

#Text=Although the ability of the Canadian Department of Indian Affairs to determine that the pole could even be removed in the first place is ethically questionable , if Hansson did not obtain proper permission from the pole ’ s rightful owners to remove the piece , his export license would have been obtained based on a false declaration and could , potentially , be challenged in court .
#Text=Return of the Pole For over 60 years the Haisla did not know the location of the totem pole , however its memory was preserved via oral traditions .
#Text=In 1991 the pole was found to be in the collection of the Museum of Ethnography in Stockholm and various Haisla confirmed this identification .
#Text=In December 1991 , with logistical help from Greenpeace , several Haisla visited Stockholm not to ask if the pole would be returned , but when .

#Text=The next year a representative of the museum visited the Haisla who insisted that they believed the museum ( but not Hansson ) acquired the pole in good faith , but that it was stolen and need to be returned .
#Text=They offered to make a replica of the pole for Sweden .
#Text=In 1994 permission was granted for Sweden to “ gift ” the pole to the Haisla .

#Text=The implications of this wording , however , caused serious issues , with the Haisla maintaining that you can not gift someone their own stolen property , and that it is not a true gift if they were required to pay for it with a replacement pole .

#Text=Negotiations continued and a group of Haisla traveled to Sweden again in 1997 where the Haisla claim that they were told that the museum wanted the piece to be preserved in a climate controlled environment , not displayed outside in the traditional way with the expectation that the pole would return to the earth .

#Text=The Haisla felt that this was financially impossible , having been given no money to display the pole by either the Swedish or Canadian governments , and that it was a challenge to their traditional cultural practices .
#Text=The museum eventually stepped down from this stipulation .
#Text=In 2000 Henry Robertson , the grandson of one of the original pole carvers , made two replica poles , one of which was sent to Sweden in a partially complete state .
#Text=He then spent a month completing the pole in the museum so that visitors could see the carving process .
#Text=At this point , the Haisla had not been able to raise the money needed to build a facility for the real pole which remained in Sweden .
#Text=In 2006 the Haisla conducted a traditional pole raising ceremony for the replica pole at the Museum of Ethnography and on 23 March the original pole was packed and shipped back to Canada .
#Text=On 1 July it returned to Kitimaat Village and is thought to be the first First Nations totem pole repatriated from Europe .
#Text=[ Image by Carlstaffanholmer via Wikimedia Commons ]
